explanation:
OS_object_token_t — need the type definition to know whether *token is an object value or a pointer-to-pointer etc., and to confirm that the pointed-to object is const (so the function cannot legally modify *token).

OS_count_sem_prop_t — definition of the struct is required to confirm that modifying count_prop->value changes the object pointed to (which is allowed by MISRA) and that no attempt is made to modify the pointer itself (e.g., by assigning to count_prop).

OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t — required to know the layout of impl and the type of impl->id (so we can verify that taking &impl->id and passing it to sem_getvalue does not modify the token or the pointer parameters).

OS_impl_count_sem_table — the table symbol is used by the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro; its type/definition may affect how the macro computes impl and whether the token expression passed into the macro could be modified.

OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — the macro definition is essential: it takes the expression '*token' as an argument. We must inspect its expansion to ensure it does not perform any assignments to that expression (which could amount to modifying the object referred to by the token or the token object itself).

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — this function is invoked (directly or indirectly) by the table/getter logic; its prototype/behavior is needed to confirm that it does not modify the token object or expect a non-const pointer (which could indicate modification).

sem_getvalue — the POSIX prototype is needed to check what is modified when calling sem_getvalue(&impl->id, &sval). Verifying that sem_getvalue only writes to the provided sval and not to impl->id or any input pointers ensures no implicit modification of objects reachable from the function parameters.
